body: I'm curious about the reasons behind this feature. Why aren't ordinary functions good enough for the same purpose? Given that Rust have default methods it shouldn't be much less ergonomic. And combination of monomorphisation and static lifetimes should converge any difference in terms of performance.

One notable case is that of the `Zero` and `One` traits, which exist solely to confer their constant value to the types which implement them. With associated constants they would be redundant, as `Sum` and `Mul` would include the additive and multiplicative identities.
@Ketsuban how would it be different than including `zero` and `one` _as functions_ into `Sum` and `Mul` traits?
Having skimmed through #27739 it looks like there're opinions about the concepts of "zero" and "one" as functions as it may give additional flexibility.

The use of associated consts could make things like `bitflags!` more pretty in my opinion, by scoping the consts in the name of the bitflags struct, much like enum variants are scoped in the name of the enum.

would love to use associated consts for array sizes for example: http://is.gd/VSee6B

```
struct Something {
    inner: [u8; Something::LENGTH]
}
```

but this will leave me at E0250

> I'm curious about the reasons behind this feature. Why aren't ordinary functions good enough for the same purpose?

I am not sure about this but I think that associated constants could allow us compile time execution for things similar to non-type template parameters as in C++ which are quite useful. Using functions wouldn't work in the example below since Rust currently has no mechanism to detect if a function can be evaluated at compile-time (constexpr as in C++ or even templates).

**Example:**
https://gist.github.com/Robbepop/da73db721c22492616f6

If the example above really works (haven't tested it, yet) things like BitFlag<N> or the shown BigInt<N> could be implemented very efficiently - not using the heap at all!

Is there any ETA on the stabilization of this feature? It would be really useful for something which I'm currently experimenting with, namely the implementation of Windows COM interop: One could add a trait that exposes each interface's GUID and/or class ID as constants, then e.g. [this API](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/br224648%28v=vs.85%29.aspx) could be mapped to Rust in a way that takes the to-be-activated class as a type parameter that implements said trait.

Of course I can work on this using nightly, but it would be nice to have some information whether the feature is going to be stabilized in the near future!
Should we block on #34344? Are there other known bugs? Are there design questions to resolve here?
There was a question on the forum [here](https://users.rust-lang.org/t/why-does-this-code-need-a-static-bound-on-a-type-when-all-it-uses-is-const/7236). Looks like a bug to me.
What is status or what would need to be done to stabilize this feature? It would be really helpful in Octavo as it would allow me to provide HMAC without any heap allocations.

@hauleth take a look at the [associated-items issues](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/labels/A-associated-items). That contains many of the bugs that exist with associated constants. I imagine many of them would need to be fixed before anyone could consider this feature "stable".

How can we accelerate this? This is a major feature and it doesn't appear to be moving or have a champion.

This is [used by Rocket](https://github.com/SergioBenitez/Rocket/issues/19#issuecomment-269052006).
Just nominating to put it in front of eyeballs again.
My understanding is that this is waiting on a re-do of const evaluation in the compiler, since it's so buggy. @eddyb ?

"Buggy" is not the best way to put it IMO, "barely does anything at all" is far closer.
@brson You can consider @solson, @oli-obk (both miri) and me (rustc) as unofficial champions (for the past several months) for const-eval-related areas.
Noted in the op that this is blocked on const_fn.
Should block on this bug https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/26847
@JoeyAcc if you need to use `feature` then 100% it will not work on anything other than nightly.

Yes, I understand that. It wasn't quite what I intended to ask.
Rather, I wanted to know if the code above even works at all, since there are apparently still issues with the feature *somewhere* (and I have no clue where exactly the breakage is currently).
It's more about the "breakage border" (or some rough approximation of it) than which Rust version I should use.
Sorry about the confusion.

Can anyone give an update on associated consts? @eddyb ?

The tracking issue here lists two items: const fn & docs. Setting aside docs, I don't know why const fn is a necessary precursor to associated consts. It seems to me that associated consts could instead be the beachhead which const fn will someday make more useful.

I also suspect the issue is incomplete; in the past there were many bugs with this feature. When I've used it more recently its seemed better, but I see some open bugs linked from here.

Personally, I'd like to have this on stable not because I *necessarily* care about compile time computation, but also because I have a lot of these `fn whatever() -> &'static str;` methods that feel more correct & ergonomic as `const WHATEVER: &'static str;`.

I don't think there are any design issues with this feature left, and I think we are certain that we want it in the language. I wonder how close it is to a point where we could stabilize *something*.

Team member @withoutboats has proposed to merge this. The next step is review by the rest of the tagged teams:

* [x] @aturon
* [x] @eddyb
* [x] @nikomatsakis
* [x] @nrc
* [x] @pnkfelix
* [x] @withoutboats

No concerns currently listed.

Once these reviewers reach consensus, this will enter its final comment period. If you spot a major issue that hasn't been raised at any point in this process, please speak up!

See [this document](https://github.com/dikaiosune/rust-dashboard/blob/master/RFCBOT.md) for info about what commands tagged team members can give me.

> A const expression (such as an array length) cannot today depend on an abstract type parameter. That is `for<T: Trait> [_; T::CONST]` is not usable; it returns a clean error.

Can the language be extended to support this in the future? Is it a matter of compiler implementation work?

@SimonSapin It's more or less the same as getting const generics to work, although a bit easier.
I don't think that limitation is specified anywhere, it's more of an implementation detail that we hope to fix.

Does `[_; T::CONST]` raise the sort of unification questions etc that the const params RFC does? If so, if its implemented before thats resolved it should be feature gated.

I guess if it does it probably can't be implemented without resolving that RFC. I just wouldn't want to get 'boxed into' a ruling because of what looks like an instastable bug fix.

Regarding object safety, would there be an implicit 'where Self: Sized' constraints on constants (since we can't write them ourselves)? Or would it just be illegal to box a trait object that has constants? 

I'd prefer the former, and have a specific instance that has been waiting on this: `Header` in hyper.

@withoutboats The conservative approach (treating it the same way we would a `T::Assoc` type, i.e. a projection) is backwards-compatible, and everything else after that is "peeking through" projections.
@eddyb I don't understand what you mean. What does "treating it the same way we would a [projection]" look like to users? Its backwards compatible with what?
@eddyb Oh I see, you're responding to the unification question not the object safety question. Sounds good. :-)

@seanmonstar The proposal I made is for associated consts to simply not be object safe. Your example is a good one; I wouldn't want to implicitly add `where Self: Sized` to these items, but I think we should add the ability to attach where clauses to them to solve this problem, just like functions have. I don't know that we should block on that though (also I have no idea how hard it is to implement).

How long have assoc consts been implemented? I was not aware they were ready for testing (only that they were sort of done/wip). I think we should perhaps advertise that they are usable and then wait a few weeks before stabilising. It seems a bit rushed to stabilise a big feature like this that is not getting much use.

I've occassionally turned this feature on when I wanted it to express intent. I've always ended up turning it off because it wasn't worth blocking stable on.

My anecdotal experience is that in 2015, when I tried these were just totally unusable (like I think even in runtime expressions you couldn't do `T::CONST`). When I tried again in 2016, I found that they work as you'd expect in a runtime context. The only thing that's been implemented recently is that concrete associated consts (`i32::CONST`) can now be used in constexpr context.

So yea for about a year now my experience with this feature has been that it works, but its not been worth moving off stable for.

Rocket apparently uses this feature, maybe someone involved in that project can give feedback on whether there have been any issues.

Things like these: https://play.rust-lang.org/?gist=052e577b29c316cbb06a9584f6006404&version=nightly&backtrace=0

still do not work, is that normal? (I know they can be worked around, but the error message could at least use some love).
Yea that's the same as `[_; T::CONST]`, its a const based on a non-concrete type.

[bitflags](https://github.com/rust-lang-nursery/bitflags) could benefit from this feature. See:
- https://github.com/rust-lang-nursery/bitflags/issues/20
- https://github.com/rust-lang-nursery/bitflags/issues/21

It would improve discoverability if for `fn foo(flags: Bar)` one could pass `foo(Bar::BAZ)` instead of `foo(BAZ)`.
@burdges Yeah that's sort of a bug. It's a limitation in the current regionck. cc @nikomatsakis
@aturon @withoutboats I've updated the issue description based on comments (and to add #41323).

@aturon @nikomatsakis @pnkfelix Are there any concerns about stabilizing this feature?

I would like to get this into FCP soon so it could get into the beta for 1.19.

@withoutboats I do have concerns, but probably they don't have to block stabilization. Primarily, I am concerned that the existing impl is "ad hoc" in various ways and that we may discover surprising things that it allows or disallows. I'm not sure how best to allay those concerns (and they apply to a lot of things that are stable anyway).

@withoutboats I'm fine signing off on the top-level design, but like @nikomatsakis feel uncertain about the state of the implementation. I'm not really sure how to gain confidence about it, though. In any case, I won't block stabilization.

There's an abstract question here: how can implementation issues block stabilization? (several other features we're pretty comfortable with the design of have similar issues - impl trait and specialization come to mind).

Here are the kinds of implementation issues that can crop up:

* Is the implementation *unsound*? Does it allow unsafety in safe code?
* Is the implementation *overly liberal*? Does it allow safe things we don't want it to allow?
* Is the implementation *overly conservative*? Does it disallow things we think should be allowed?

These seem like progressively less serious as you go down the list. Another axis each wrongness in the implementation needs to be considered on is its egregiousness.

For example, I think we should block stabilizing this the fact that consts are considered object safe today. This is both too liberal and very egregious.

But that we don't accept some uses of associated consts in other associated consts is both too conservative (not as big an issue) and not particularly egregious, and I'm comfortable not blocking on that.

@withoutboats I think what this rubric comes down to is: how likely is it that we will need/want to make breaking changes to the implementation in the future?

I'm not at all expert in our const system, so I'm basically happy to trust that those that are have sussed out the points of overly-liberal or overly-conservative behavior.

@withoutboats 

I don't want to expose the current associated const system to user code because it *will* break horribly (well, slightly less horribly than a few months ago, but still). We are going to integrate MIRI with rustc soon-ish, and that should bring things to a saner state.

> I don't want to expose the current associated const system to user code because it will break horribly

Can you be more expansive? The known bugs do not seem significant to me, and I've been using it considerably since proposing the merge and it has worked well.

After some discussion, I feel reasonably good about putting this into FCP for stabilization, but I would feel better if we could assemble:

- A list of known shortcomings, linked to from the top of this bug
- Clear links to the tests (ideally, centralized or tagged in some way) showing all the things that work as expected (or don't, as the case may be)

@withoutboats has promised to do some of this. For the record, I think I'd like this all the time as we stabilize major features (or maybe even minor ones).
:bell: **This is now entering its final comment period**, as per the [review above](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/29646#issuecomment-289397164). :bell:

@JoeyAcc I don't see how that's possible. I get:
```rust
error[E0283]: type annotations required: cannot resolve `_: Foo`
  --> <anon>:18:20
   |
18 |     const Y: i32 = Foo::X;
   |                    ^^^^^^
   |
   = note: required by `Foo::X`
```

Ah yes I see. It fails with a completely different error, and that fact slipped by me.
Oops, carry on :)
The final comment period is now complete.
@nikomatsakis I've updated the first post to enumerate the shortcomings of this feature that I know about. I also checked the `run-pass` tests and they seemed comprehensive to me.
@withoutboats Isn't "Types referenced in associated consts must be 'static" solved already?

Yes! I didn't see you'd fixed that, I thought you just fixed the using `Self` in default associated consts.

There's a run-pass test that needs to be updated then, I'll PR..
Will this make it in for 1.19?
I was hoping so but we just discovered a soundness bug at #41323, not sure if that will be fixed in time
The soundness bug #41323 has been closed. Anything else preventing stabilizing?
Still needs docs. Also the cut off for 1.19 is today I believe. I think we're looking at 1.20 now but maybe we could squeeze it through? Personally unclear about the policy on this.
https://doc.rust-lang.org/nightly/unstable-book/language-features/associated-consts.html has the basics, would need to be adapted for the reference/book.
Looks like it'll be 1.20.
If I wanted to get this moving to stable now, are those docs sufficient? Would I just send a PR removing all the feature gate stuff?

> If I wanted to get this moving to stable now, are those docs sufficient?

Sending in a PR for them would be, yeah. We might iterate a bit in the PR, but the docs requirement is more of a "a PR must be sent in for docs" than "the docs must be merged"

The original comment has #34344 and #39211 listed as a blocker and both of those are open, although with comments along the lines of "this probably works". I'd be nice to have those resolved concretely one way or the other.
@shepmaster We decided those wouldn't block stabilization of associated consts.

> We decided those wouldn't block stabilization of associated consts.

@eddyb cool. I've edited the comment to strike those out like the no-longer-blocking `const fn`.

So we have current stabilized some part of the existing feature in https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/42809 (and there are docs). I think it'd be really great if we updated the description with a more comprehensive write-up of what *does work* and what *does not* -- though the existing listing of shortcomings seems like a good start.
Does the stabilization of this feature mean that generic fixed-sized arrays will be supported soon?
@mikeyhew The original message cites `let y: [i32; <T as Foo>::X];` explicitly an something that does **not** work. And even if it did, that still doesn’t give integer generics.
@mikeyhew You can follow the progress on that feature on this rfc: rust-lang/rfcs#2000

@nikomatsakis I think the list of shortcomings is an accurate summary of what doesn't work. What does work is "everything else," isn't it? What is missing from the tracking issue that isn't covered in the new docs for the feature?

@mikeyhew That is a different feature, although it does depend on lifting the limitations of array lengths not being able to depend on generic parameters, that were punted on for the stabilization of associated consts (see earlier discussion).

Today found that lifetime in associated consts doesn't defaults to `'static`, as it must as according to [stabilized in 1.17.0](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/39265) [rfc](https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/blob/master/text/1623-static.md). So: 
`trait Foo { const FOO: &str = "dsad"; }` gives `expected lifetime parameter` error, while `trait Foo { const FOO: &'static str = "dsad"; }` is valid. Same goes for struct, enum and union impl blocks.
@Object905 Relevant discussion in https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/38831
Should this be closed? All boxes are checked off, and https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/42809 was merged
And it's available in beta AFAICT
Yes, it will be in 1.20.

Maybe I’m not seeing the point but as long as “Associated consts in const expressions must be concrete” is still a restriction I do not see any use of associated constants in traits. 

Yet you can add them such that all of the error messaged presented in #32344 are still very there and very misleading.

Shouldn’t one simply forbid associated constants in traits unless that restriction is lifted? I dont’t think that it was a good idea merge #42809 (i.e. remove the feature gate) with a feature in such an incomplete state.
@nwin It's not "in const expressions" - but rather "in types", i.e. array types.
@frehberg When const generics are implemented you will be able to do that yourself, for example with an `impl<T, const N: usize> MyLenTrait for [T; N]`
Anyone landing here from googling "associated const", this was released in Rust 1.20, see the announcement: https://blog.rust-lang.org/2017/08/31/Rust-1.20.html

Also, if anyone is looking for the documentation of this, it's here: https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/reference/items.html#associated-constants

(It was surprisingly hard to find.)

> using an associated const as an array size

Probably related to #42863, #44168, #44774 ?

> Furthermore, using an associated const as an array size does not appear to work:

This usage of associated const was not stabilized, as documented in this issue (it doesn't work on nightly either, and probably won't work until `const`-generics implementation improves).

Having const fn is this feature still required ? Of course it'd require to have const fn in traits as well.
(For now no array size can be given using either associated const or const fn)

((Or one could be the desugaring'of the other ))
@zpgaal this feature is implemented and stable, so regardless of it being "required", it has to stay!
@steveklabnik It seems like rustdoc does not generate documentation for associated constants in structs. Is this a bug?
Oh I see. Please file a bug separately?

> Oh I see. Please file a bug separately?

See #52260.
